Another important factor for ORR and OER activities is the geometrical effects of catalysts. For example, Kakizaki et al . demonstrated that in the case of β-phase manganese dioxide, the OER activity depends on the exposed crystal facet on the catalyst surfaces.
32 These facet dependencies were also reported for LaCoO 3
16 and LiMn 1.5Ni 0.5O 4.
33 Furthermore, some studies have reported that ORR and OER activities can be improved by bending or distortion of polyhedra comprising active metal and O atoms.
34− 36 Recently, the control of crystal phases was investigated to enhance ORR and OER activities. Long et al . compared the ORR activities of two distinct cobalt (Co)–manganese (Mn) spinel oxides bearing a cubic and a tetragonal phase, respectively.
37 Additionally, crystalline polymorphism affects ORR and OER activities on manganese oxide,
38, 39 iron oxyhydroxide,
40 and palladium/copper alloy.
41 Besides such microscopic geometry, macroscopic morphologies are also keys to enhancing the ORR and OER activities. Several studies have attempted to construct catalyst nanostructures to enlarge surface areas and improve mass transports during the electrochemical ORR and OER processes. These catalyst nanostructures include enriched porous nanofibers and nanorods,
42 template-constructed porous structures,
43 and metal–organic framework structures.
